person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_321.name: GeorgeFordyce
person_321.description: Scottish physician, lecturer on medicine and chemist who worked in London. FRSL.

person_144.name: JosephBanks
person_144.description: A member of the Lincolnshire gentry, Banks sailed as a botanist on James Cook's first voyage to the Pacific (1768-1771). Elected President of the Royal Society of London in 1778 he served for forty-two years until just before his death. The dominant figure in the running of English science during that time, he became one of Davy's patrons and ultimately Davy succeeded him to the Presidency. FRSL.

person_142.name: CharlesBlagden
person_142.description: Physician who kept a revealing diary for most of his life. A friend of Joseph Banks serving as a Secretary of the Royal Society of London, 1784-1797; Knighted 1792. FRSL

person_205.name: Daniel CarlssonSolander
person_205.description: Swedish-born naturalist who worked at the British Museum cataloguing their natural history collections according to the Linnean system. Close to Banks, he accompanied him on various vayages including the Endeavour expedition to the Pacific. FRSL.

person_265.name: Peter SimonPallas
person_265.description: Prussian explorer, geologist and botanist, who wrote 'Second Voyage de Pallas, ou Voyages entrpris dans les gouvernmens meridionaux de l'empire de Russie, pendant les annees 1793 et 94'

person_016.name: JosephPriestley
person_016.description: Unitarian and political radical forced into exile in Pennsylvania. As a natural philospher and chemist who retained belief in phlogiston, he discovered oxygen and nitrous oxide though not under those names. FRSL.

person_224.name: Carl WilhelmScheele
person_224.description: Swedish-German pharmaceutical chemist. One of the discoverers of what would later be called oxygen (1771) as well as other chemical elements including what Davy renamed chlorine.

person_023.name: RichardKirwan
person_023.description: Irish chemist, mineralogist and geologist who accused fellow geologist, James Hutton, of athiesm following publication of his Theory of the Earth (1788). FRSL

person_389.name: Pierre JosephMacquer
person_389.description: French chemist who published his Dictionnaire de Chymie in 1766 and later opposed Lavoisier's theories.

person_033.name: Torbern OlafBergman
person_033.description: Swedish chemist and mineralogist. At some point Davy acquired a set of letters from Bergman to Franz Schwediaur written in the 1780s which are retained in the Royal Institution (RI MS HD/27/A). ForMemRSL.

person_146.name: JamesWatt
person_146.description: A Scottish scientific instrument maker who studied with the chemist Joseph Black at Glasgow University. He developed the separate condenser for steam engines which increased their effieciency significantly. He took out a twenty-five-year patent (ending in 1800) and moved to Birmingham where he went into partnership with the businessman and industrialist Matthew Boulton. They made their fortune by having an effective monopoly of manufacturing steam engines. A friend of Thomas Beddoes, he met Davy on a number of occasions and Davy gave the oration at the unveiling of Watt's statue in Greenock. FRSL.

person_927.name: WilliamIrvine
person_927.description: FRSE 18th-century British doctor and chemist who served as assistant to Joseph Black in many of his important experiments.

person_922.name: AdairCrawford
person_922.description: A British chemist, physician, and fellow of the Royal Society. He was a pioneer in the development of calorimetric methods for measuring the specific heat capacity of substances and the heat of chemical reactions.

place_990.name: Siberia
place_990.description: a vast Russian province encompassing most of Northern Asia, with terrain spanning tundra, coniferous forest and mountain ranges

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.
